title: WWE's Cesaro spills on Brock Lesnar match
text:
Cesaro is determined to face Brock Lesnar (Picture: WWE)Cesaro is still planning his match with Brock Lesnar in the back of his head.

The former Intercontinental, United States and tag team champion admitted he is still a little disappointed his pairing with Paul Heyman five years ago didn’t lead to a blockbuster storyline with the former UFC superstar, and he revealed he’s always plotting potential bouts with everyone on the WWE roster.

Speaking in Los Angeles, he told Metro.co.uk: ‘One hundred percent! I still have my imaginary match with Brock in the back of my head. That’s what I do, with anybody on the roster, I’m thinking about what I could do. That’s how my brain works, it could be anybody!

‘When it’s someone new, “what could we do?” Of course, I think me and Lesnar would have a pretty good match. Especially with the right build-up, it’d be awesome, and something the fans would want to see.’

When Cesaro was endorsed by Heyman on-screen after WrestleMania 30, he thought it would be the spark that lit his career and took it to the next level, but the focus shifted back to Brock and the Swiss Cyborg found himself slipping back down the pecking order.

‘Of course I wish it had gone different, let’s be honest,’ he candidly admitted during our in-depth conversation.

‘But to be fair, I also wish I’d done stuff differently. A lot of people point fingers, but I always try to look at what I could have done. I want to learn from the experience, and I’m also very grateful because I learned a lot from Paul Heyman, I learned a lot about how things work.

‘I’m trying to make the best of it! Looking back, I can make jokes about it, and poke fun. But I’m all about climbing the mountains, so let’s get the pickax out and start climbing again!’

Brock Lesnar and Paul Heyman (Picture: WWE)

Cesaro takes on Richocet on Raw (Picture: WWE)

For the 38-year-old star – regarded by many fans as one of the most talented and versatile performers on the entire roster – there is some professional frustration when it comes to part-time names like Lesnar, or returning legends like The Undertaker and Goldberg coming back into high profile spots, sometimes at the expense of the current full-time names.

‘As a fan, you enjoy the nostalgia moments, but I feel it has to be done in the right way. And here’s the thing, I want to remember my heroes like I remember them! And of course, that doesn’t mean they have to look and be like they were, but they have to be in a certain way,’ he explained.

‘With [the Saudi Arabia and Australia stadium] shows you can see some spectacular things that you never thought was possible, I just think we also need to focus on people who are here on a weekly and daily basis, who are doing all the work.

‘At the end of the day, you will not see Goldberg come to Birmingham, England and do a live event – you just will not! Sorry to disappoint you, spoiler alert, he’s not coming! But there’s a lot of superstars who are going to be there.’

Cesaro explained the need to adapt in an industry where everything changes so quickly – sometimes even just as a show gets underway.

He pointed to his rival-turned-team mate storyline with Irish star Sheamus – who has become his best friend – as a perfect example of this.

‘I was like “I don’t wanna be in another team – especially with the big Irish fella!” It was one of those, I wanted to carve my own place, and then that happened. I was like, this is so stupid,’ he laughed. The best part of that team was obviously the friendship that grew out of it.

‘For the viewer, you can see the team grow from two guys who were literally fighting each other in a best of seven series, to become best friends. That journey, you saw it every week. I feel there’s not that many long term storylines in WWE anymore, but that was a long term story! That wasn’t planned, trust me!’

For Cesaro, as important as the characters and promos are in WWE, he feels the emphasis should always be on the in-ring action, and the magical escape it can provide for fans.

‘To me, the most important part of what we do will always be the wrestling, that’s what makes us different,’ he smiled. ‘I get it, talking is very important. But to be fair, if I want to see somebody talk for an hour, I’ll go and see a stand-up comedy show. That’s what they do.

‘English is my second language, I think I speak it pretty well, but I can go anywhere in the world and wrestle and people understand. That’s it. We go to so many countries and that’s what I love to do, to see them lose their minds – it’s priceless.’

*Friday Night SmackDown airs every week at 1am on Sky Sports Arena and Main Event. WWE will be touring the UK next month with a huge double TV taping featuring both Raw and SmackDown superstars in Manchester on 8 November.
